title: (x) what do you call the words like "and" , "or"?
content:
I think it was just posted a week or so ago, but I can't remember  
what those words are called or what foundries sell them as a font.  
Thru words or something like that?  
Thanks.
author: carriedrazin

comments.content:
Logotypes? Or catch words?  
See these threads:  
 [The "and" glyph](http://web.archive.org/web/20141109174937/http:/typophile.com/node/66680)  
 [Show bill style self-contained words](http://web.archive.org/web/20141109174937/http:/typophile.com/node/63150)  
 [Catchwords](http://web.archive.org/web/20141109174937/http:/typophile.com/node/6169)  
 [Which feature for catchwords and catchwords.alt?](http://web.archive.org/web/20141109174937/http:/typophile.com/node/58223)

<cite>This is not Grammarophile, folks! ;-)</cite>

The term "grammar" apparently derives from a Greek term meaning "art of letters," whereas "type" comes from Greek <cite>impression</cite> or <cite>cast</cite>. Maybe "Grammarphile" would be a better name for this place, since so much talk of non-cast letters going on here : )

This thread, though, definitely belongs at in some kind of philology website. But would that be called "philogyphile", "logyphile", or simple "philology"?--since "Philology" itself means "love of words."

carriedrazin, are you sure you don't mean stereotype?

[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stereotype](http://web.archive.org/web/20141109174937/http:/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stereotype "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stereotype")
